user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskEntryPoint:
```c
void OS_TaskEntryPoint(osal_id_t task_id)
{
    osal_task_entry task_entry;

    if (OS_TaskPrepare(task_id, &task_entry) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        if (task_entry != NULL)
        {
            (*task_entry)();
        }
    }

    /* If the function returns, treat as a normal exit and do the proper cleanup */
    OS_TaskExit();
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
(*task_entry)();
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls through a function pointer variable (osal_task_entry task_entry). Function types cannot be const-qualified in C, so you cannot make the pointee a const-qualified function type. Also the local variable must be assignable because OS_TaskPrepare(&task_entry) initializes it, so making the pointer itself const is not possible here. Therefore Rule 8.13 is not violated for the call expression (*task_entry)().
